Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for "The Privacy Enhancing Technologies" Symposium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Privacy Enhancing Technology Symposium (PETS) is a leading venue for privacy technology research. Since starting in 2000, PETS has brought together researchers in privacy-related areas including Internet and other data systems and communication networks. Student attendance at PETS is an important part of graduate education in privacy. The 2016 Symposium will be held in Darmstadt Germany.

This grant provides travel support to encourage participation at PETS by students who would normally find it difficult to attend. Criteria for selection include evidence of a serious interest in the field, as demonstrated by research areas. Preference will be offered to those with papers but inadequate travel funding from their organization. Organizers will make particular efforts to encourage participation of women and under-represented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project used funding from the National Science Foundation to increase the participation and representation of students at the Privacy Enhancing Symposium (PETS), held in Darmstadt, Germany in 2016. PETS is the premier venue for novel applied and/or theoretical research into the design, analysis, experimentation, or fielding of privacy-enhancing technologies. It brings together privacy experts from around the world to present and discuss recent advances and new perspectives on research in privacy.

Students were selected from among the applicants by a four-member committee, which included long-term members of the privacy enhancing technologies research and practitioner communities. The selection was made based on the students' likely contribution to the symposium and their future potential contribution to the field of privacy enhancing technologies.  Priority was given to underrepresented groups and students who had a paper accepted into the symposium.

The project supported the partial costs of travel for sixteen students, enabling them to attend the symposium. The students thus had the opportunity to learn about the latest research on privacy enhancing technologies, and to interact with both peers and leading researchers in the field, contributing to their professional development. Several of the students also presented their own research, either at the symposium or the associated HotPETS workshop, and received feedback on their work. The project also increased participation in the symposium by underrepresented groups; more than half the recipients were women or minorities.
